Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "MS login is faling" (#6033) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Every MS live.com login brings me to a 500 error on nuget.org.

# Steps:
* https://www.nuget.org
* log in using the nuget account
* follow popup to sign in with Microsoft
* successful login at MS

# Result:
https://www.nuget.org/Errors/500?aspxerrorpath=/users/account/authenticate/return
Oops!
Error 500 - Internal Server Error

# Expected:
Login upgrade and access to nuget.org

# Impact
Since I cannot use nuget.org with the old account anymore, I'm effectively denied access to manage my packages.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "project.assets.json is not being updated when restoring" (#6999) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

I recently updated all of our services to target .NET Core 2.1 and everything worked great on my one machine and on someone else's machine. However, most other people were running into an issue like this:

```
Errors in C:\Users\joschm\Intentional\services\src\ContentServiceFrontend\ContentServiceFrontend.csproj
    NU1701: Package 'Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols.OpenIdConnect 5.2.0' was restored using '.NETFramework,Version=v4.6.1' instead of the project target framework '.NETCoreApp,Version=v2.1'. This package may not be fully compatible with your project.
    NU1202: Package Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Abstractions 2.1.0 is not compatible with netcoreapp2.1 (.NETCoreApp,Version=v2.1). Package Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Abstractions 2.1.0 does not support any target frameworks.
    NU1202: Package Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Abstractions 2.1.0 is not compatible with netcoreapp2.1 (.NETCoreApp,Version=v2.1) / win10-x64. Package Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Abstractions 2.1.0 does not support any target frameworks.
```

Nothing seemed to fix it - I tried nuking every nuget cache I could find, reinstalling Visual Studio, etc. 
I then compared the `project.assets.json` file on the machine that worked with the one that didn't and found that the assets file was not updating properly.

This is from the machine that didn't work:
```json
"Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols.OpenIdConnect/5.2.0": {
  "type": "package",
  "dependencies": {
    "Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols": "5.2.0",
    "NETStandard.Library": "1.6.1",
    "Newtonsoft.Json": "10.0.1",
    "System.Dynamic.Runtime": "4.3.0",
    "System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt": "5.2.0"
  },
  "compile": {
    "lib/net45/Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols.OpenIdConnect.dll": {}
  },
  "runtime": {
    "lib/net45/Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols.OpenIdConnect.dll": {}
  }
},
"Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Abstractions/2.1.0": {
  "sha512": "yK69ZDd9mDqEZoDvvevHRRSM+ykJwA4xU1d8VnNm5pSXbBZA9acLfj4QuaqCtjgggFFzodcT/K2LNp5Pcm+Eaw==",
  "type": "package",
  "path": "microsoft.entityframeworkcore.abstractions/2.1.0",
  "files": [
    ".signature.p7s",
    "lib/netstandard2.0/Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Abstractions.xml",
    "microsoft.entityframeworkcore.abstractions.2.1.0.nupkg.sha512",
    "microsoft.entityframeworkcore.abstractions.nuspec"
  ]
}
```

You can see that there are no DLLs listed for `Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Abstractions` and only `net45` DLLs listed for `Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols.OpenIdConnect`.

This is on the machine where it worked:
```json
"Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols.OpenIdConnect/5.2.0": {
    "type": "package",
    "dependencies": {
        "Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols": "5.2.0",
        "NETStandard.Library": "1.6.1",
        "Newtonsoft.Json": "10.0.1",
        "System.Dynamic.Runtime": "4.3.0",
        "System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt": "5.2.0"
    },
    "compile": {
        "lib/netstandard1.4/Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols.OpenIdConnect.dll": {}
    },
    "runtime": {
        "lib/netstandard1.4/Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols.OpenIdConnect.dll": {}
    }
},
"Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Abstractions/2.1.0": {
"type": "package",
"compile": {
"lib/netstandard2.0/Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Abstractions.dll": {}
},
"runtime": {
"lib/netstandard2.0/Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Abstractions.dll": {}
}
}
```

If I delete the `project.assets.json` file on the machine then everything works and it recreates it with the format that works.
This seems like a pretty gnarly bug (and took down most of our engineers for the day) - any ideas what's happening?
Why would `nuget restore -force` not blow away this file?

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): Nuget.exe

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.6.2.5055

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 2.1.300

VS version (if appropriate): 15.8.0 Preview 2

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): 17682.1000

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Include ProjectReference in the nuget package lib and not as a dependency" (#6998) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
This is related to #3891

1. ProjA has a project reference to ProjB
2. I implemented the workaround in #3891, so ProjB.dll now appears in the nupkg lib folder
3. Pack ProjA

Actual:  ProjB is still listed as a <dependency> in the nuspec
Expected: ProjB should not be listed as a dependency, as this will require me to publish a nuget package for it 

Note: Setting PrivateAsset="All" on the ProjectReference element will cause ProjB to not be listed as a dependency, however this is causing build failures because ProjB needs to be made available for build etc.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "dotnet restore on 2.1 preview1 throws error instead of warning when project files are "missing"" (#6651) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @christiansparre on March 8, 2018 17:22_

I was playing around with 2.1 preview 1 and trying to get a simple ASP.NET Core 2.1 preview1 app up and running on docker using the VS docker tools. But my `docker-compose build` failed because `dotnet restore` on 2.1 throws error `MSB3202: The project file "/src/SomeApp.SomeLib/SomeApp.SomeLib.csproj" was not found.`

But it is not isolated to docker, see the repo below where there is also a repro for 2.0 and 2.1 outside docker. And they behave very differently. Yes this is not really "normal" restore behavior, but all dotnet docker examples and the VS tooling does it this way with multistage builds and they explicitly suppress MSB3202 using `-nowarn:msb3202,nu1503`

I have not been able to find any known issues by searching the different dotnet repos. Is `dotnet restore` throwing errors, instead of warnings, a new expected behavior?

Also this is the most correct place I could find to post the issue, please redirect me elsewhere if there is a better place for it :)

## Steps to reproduce

Code to reproduce can be found here: https://github.com/christiansparre/DotNet2.1RestoreBehavior

* Create ASP.NET Core 2.1 web site
  * with Docker support (I used Linux)
* Add another project, and reference in web app (does not really matter)
* Change the Dockerfile to use the correct image versions (defaults to 2.1 that does not exist yet)
* Run `docker-compose build`

## Expected  behavior

Expected `dotnet restore` to complete with out errors or warnings because of `-nowarn:msb3202,nu1503` arguments


## Actual behavior

Restore failed with

`
/usr/share/dotnet/sdk/2.1.300-preview1-008174/NuGet.targets(239,5): error MSB3202: The project file "/src/SomeApp.SomeLib/SomeApp.SomeLib.csproj" was not found. [/src/SomeApp.sln]

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.org API rate limits for package updates" (#24) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
|Spec wiki|Discussion issue|
|----------|------------------|
|*None*|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4679|

We have been working on improving the package submission workflow to reduce the overall time it takes to publish the package (right from package push/upload) till it's available for consumption and search. 

As mentioned on our [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20180201/NuGet-package-publishing-workflow-behind-the-scenes.html), the package availability gets degraded multi fold whenever there is a large number package uploads/updates by a single owner that clogs the package submission pipeline. Until we are able to scale to handle the large submission rate, in the short-term, we plan to reduce the rate limits for package pushes or deletes (unlist) per user.

The current [documented rate limits](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/api/rate-limits#package-push-and-unlist) will be updated to the following new limits once implemented. This change will go live, **soon** (within a week or two):

## Package Push and Unlist

| API | Limit Type | Limit Value | API usecase | 
|:---|:---|:---|:--- |
**PUT** `/api/v2/package` | API Key | ~~100 / minute~~ **250 / hour** | Upload a new NuGet package (version) via v2 push endpoint 
**DELETE** `/api/v2/package/{id}/{version}` | API Key | ~~100 / minute~~ **50 / hour** | Unlist a NuGet package (version) via v2 endpoint
